intro: Allium cupani f. hirtovaginatum, commonly known as the hairy-stalked garlic. This botanical variant is a cultivated form of Allium cupani, characterized by its distinctive hairy sheath on the stem. It is native to regions of Central Asia and has been introduced to various parts of the world for its ornamental and culinary value. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring narrow, grass-like leaves and small, spherical bulbs. Its flowers are usually white or pale purple, arranged in a dense, umbel-like cluster.
